dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, Joe Biden administration's tariff cuts from over 21% to just 3%—that's a massive drop, right? But then China retaliated hard.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, Joe Biden administration's tariff cuts from over twenty one percent to just three percent-that's a massive drop, right? But then China retaliated hard.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, then-US President Donald Trumps administration hiked the tariff rate on imports from China from slightly over 3% to more than 21% a level unseen in the US since before World War II.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they upped their tariffs on US goods from like 8% to nearly 19%, which honestly made American products more competitive there, weirdly enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they upped their tariffs on U S goods from like eight percent to nearly nineteen percent, which honestly made American products more competitive there, weirdly enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This prompted China to retaliate with higher tariffs on US imports from about 8% to some 19%. As China also lowered its tariffs on imports from all other countries, it reduced the competitiveness of US goods in the Chinese market by an even greater amount.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And then the Phase One agreement in 2020 just pushed tariffs even higher. It's like a tariff tug-of-war with no clear winner.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And then the Phase One agreement in twenty twenty just pushed tariffs even higher. It's like a tariff tug-of-war with no clear winner.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of 2019, Trump and Xi reached a phase one agreement that froze the tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, the WTO actually ruled that Biden's tariffs were legal, which is uh, kind of surprising given how aggressive they were.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, the W T O actually ruled that Biden's tariffs were legal, which is uh, kind of surprising given how aggressive they were.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In any case, a WTO panel ruled in 2020 that the Trump tariffs are incompatible with Americas legal obligation to abide by the organizations rules.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but here's the thing—those lower tariffs saved US households a ton. Removing them could raise the cost of living by two percentage points.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but here's the thing-those lower tariffs saved U S households a ton. Removing them could raise the cost of living by two percentage points.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taken together, these effects would permanently reduce the cost of living to Americans by about one percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is huge—that's like a $500 billion hit to household income every single year. Oof.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is huge-that's like a five hundred dollars billion hit to household income every single year. Oof.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Put another way, this would be equivalent of an increase in US household income by more than $250 billion per year (1% of US GDP in 2022).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just consumers; half of US imports from China are luxury goods, so American manufacturers would face higher input costs too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just consumers; half of U S imports from China are luxury goods, so American manufacturers would face higher input costs too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: About 40% of US imports from China are parts, components, and intermediate goods, so removing the Trump tariffs would also lower input costs for American service providers and manufacturers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, less competitive pressure means prices go up for goods from Mexico, Vietnam… basically everywhere. It's a ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, less competitive pressure means prices go up for goods from Mexico, Vietnam... basically everywhere. It's a ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Chinese imports become cheaper, competitive pressure on other producers would rise, leading to lower prices on goods made in Mexico, India, Vietnam, and even the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And politically, over 80% of voters say they're better off now than when Biden took office. That's a pretty strong stat.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And politically, over eighty percent of voters say they're better off now than when Biden took office. That's a pretty strong stat.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a recent poll, just 14% of American voters reported being better off financially now than when Biden took office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then why even consider raising tariffs again? It feels like such a risky move heading into an election year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then why even consider raising tariffs again? It feels like such a risky move heading into an election year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? The article suggests it might be about looking tough on China, giving Republicans less ammo. But economically, it's messy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? The article suggests it might be about looking tough on China, giving Republicans less ammo. But economically, it's messy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is said that Biden does not want to give the Republicans a reason to say that he is soft on China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And if China doesn't lower their tariffs in response, US exporters lose big time in that market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And if China doesn't lower their tariffs in response, U S exporters lose big time in that market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This would benefit the competitiveness of US goods in the Chinese market, thereby bolstering jobs and incomes not only for US exporters, but also for their input suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So it's like, short-term politics versus long-term pain for households and businesses. Not an easy call.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's like, short-term politics versus long-term pain for households and businesses. Not an easy call.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and with voters naming cost of living as their top concern? Timing is everything here.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and with voters naming cost of living as their top concern? Timing is everything here.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Biden is facing a highly contentious election next year, and the rising cost of living is voters number one economic concern.

artist_script:
HostA: Okay, so, Joe Biden administration's tariff cuts from over 21% to just 3%—that’s a massive drop, right? But then China retaliated hard.
HostB: Yeah, they upped their tariffs on US goods from like 8% to nearly 19%, which honestly made American products more competitive there, weirdly enough.
HostA: Exactly! And then the Phase One agreement in 2020 just pushed tariffs even higher. It’s like a tariff tug-of-war with no clear winner.
HostB: But wait, the WTO actually ruled that Biden’s tariffs were legal, which is uh, kind of surprising given how aggressive they were.
HostA: True, but here’s the thing—those lower tariffs saved US households a ton. Removing them could raise the cost of living by two percentage points.
HostB: Which is huge—that’s like a $500 billion hit to household income every single year. Oof.
HostA: And it’s not just consumers; half of US imports from China are luxury goods, so American manufacturers would face higher input costs too.
HostB: Plus, less competitive pressure means prices go up for goods from Mexico, Vietnam… basically everywhere. It’s a ripple effect.
HostA: And politically, over 80% of voters say they’re better off now than when Biden took office. That’s a pretty strong stat.
HostB: But then why even consider raising tariffs again? It feels like such a risky move heading into an election year.
HostA: Right? The article suggests it might be about looking tough on China, giving Republicans less ammo. But economically, it’s messy.
HostB: Totally. And if China doesn’t lower their tariffs in response, US exporters lose big time in that market.
HostA: So it’s like, short-term politics versus long-term pain for households and businesses. Not an easy call.
HostB: Yeah, and with voters naming cost of living as their top concern? Timing is everything here.
